medical: SUBJECTIVE: The patient is here for a follow-up. The patient has a history of lupus, currently on Plaquenil 200-mg b.i.d. Eye report was noted and appreciated. The patient states that she is having some aches and pains of the hands and elbows that started recently a few weeks ago. She denied having any trauma. She states that the pain is bothering her. She denies having any fevers, chills, or any joint effusion or swelling at this point. She noted also that there is some increase in her hair loss in the recent times. OBJECTIVE: The patient is alert and oriented. General physical exam is unremarkable. Musculoskeletal exam reveals positive tenderness in both lateral epicondyles of both elbows, no effusion. Hand examination is unremarkable today. The rest of the musculoskeletal exam is unremarkable. ASSESSMENT: Epicondylitis, both elbows, possibly secondary to lupus flare-up. PLAN: We will inject both elbows with 40-mg of Kenalog mixed with 1 cc of lidocaine. The posterior approach was chosen under sterile conditions. The patient tolerated both procedures well. I will obtain CBC and urinalysis today. If the patient's pain does not improve, I will consider adding methotrexate to her therapy. Sample Doctor M.D.
layman:
**SUBJECTIVE:**  
The patient came for a follow‑up visit. She has lupus and is taking Plaquenil 200 mg twice a day. She had an eye exam that was noted and appreciated. She says she has started to feel aches and pains in her hands and elbows a few weeks ago. She has not had any injuries. The pain is bothering her. She does not have fever, chills, or swelling in her joints right now. She also mentioned that her hair loss has increased recently.  

**OBJECTIVE:**  
The patient is awake, alert, and oriented. Her overall physical exam is normal. On the musculoskeletal exam, both outer elbows feel tender, but there is no swelling. Her hands look normal today. The rest of the musculoskeletal exam is normal.  

**ASSESSMENT:**  
Tendon inflammation (epicondylitis) in both elbows, likely related to a lupus flare.  

**PLAN:**  
We will give a steroid injection (40 mg Kenalog mixed with 1 cc lidocaine) in both elbows using a posterior approach under sterile conditions. The patient tolerated the injections well. I will order a CBC and urinalysis today. If her pain does not improve, I may add methotrexate to her treatment.  

— Sample Doctor M.D.
